content.title: Chez Ambroise, the meeting place for lovers of Ivorian food

introduction.small: End the night with the smart set of Abidjan, feet in sand and eyes on the stove.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chez Ambroise, the meeting place for lovers of Ivorian food

paragraphs.text:
The maquis are small family-owned restaurants, very popular in Ivory Coast, suitable to surprises and discoveries. Chez Ambroise is one that will not forget anytime soon. There is barely any decoration, a mere dozen tables under a big tent, located in a small street across the main boulevard. Right next to you, expect local singers, tom-tom players and groups of acrobats to set the night on fire.

The ambiance becomes really festive and radiant smiles are a dime a dozen. On the menu, do not pass by the skewers, considered by many to be the best in Abidjan, just like the grilled fish and the braised chicken served with attiéké (cassava couscous), yam fries or alloco (plantain fried in oil). There may be a bit of waiting, so order some local beer (best enjoyed in moderation) in the meantime. The servings are copious, and all food lovers leave satisfied!

Chez Ambroise
44, rue F28
(left on Boulevard Lorraine towards the Sainte-Thérèse de Marcory Church)
Abidjan

+225 05 78 36 00

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Restaurant-Chez-Ambroise/

Menu: around 2,960 XOF

content.title: Abokouamékro Reserve, an exceptional site

introduction.small: Surrounded by both forest and savannah, discover the natural heritage of Abokouamékro and take in the astonishing landscapes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Abokouamékro Reserve, an exceptional site

paragraphs.text:
About fifty kilometres north of Abidjan lies one of the most remarkable natural sites. Running along the border with Ghana, the Abokouamékro Reserve was created in 1986 to develop the Lake region. More than 20,000 hectares are home to wildlife, mostly from the Comoé and Marahoué National Parks and South African reserves – some of the species were considered extinct in Ivory Coast just a few decades ago.

Among the varieties reintroduced here, antelopes, buffaloes, hartebeests and giraffes live in complete freedom, although poaching has still sometimes endangered the park's ecosystem in recent years. As the Ivorian authorities have recognised this problem, visits take place in 4x4 vehicles accompanied by a guide or a forest ranger, who will help you to find your way through the forest, savannah and palm trees. And while you are not necessarily guaranteed to catch a glimpse of all the animals, it's still worth taking a trip out to the Abokouamékro reserve because of its stunning landscapes interspersed with rivers, at the centre of which you can set up camp. The lush green valleys, dominated by the hill known as “des Ambassadeurs”, promise breathtaking panoramas.

Abokouamékro Game Reserve (RAF – Réserve de Faune d'Abokouamékro)
Yamoussoukro

https://www.tourisme.gouv.ci/accueil/sitetourdetail/la-reserve-de-faune-d-abokouamekro988

content.title: Lepic Villa Hotel, personalisation and pure aesthetics

introduction.small: In the affluent district of Cocody, this villa of contemporary architecture, and former residence of the first governor of Abidjan, now houses a luxurious boutique hotel.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lepic Villa Hotel, personalisation and pure aesthetics

paragraphs.text:
In the heart of a tropical garden, far from the urban frenzy of Abidjan, the building at the end of rue Lepic, built in 1980, follows all the rules of contemporary architecture with its pure lines and its infinity pool. With Spa, bar, restaurant and even a gym, at first glance it is difficult to imagine that Villa Lepic is a comfortable boutique hotel with 18 bright and stylised rooms. While it of course provides a service worthy of the greatest establishments, it does not forget to cater to even your smallest desires, at any given moment. In the restaurant, the chef provides the same level of service by concocting all the culinary delights your heart could desire using fresh, local produce. Families are particularly well taken care of, with baby equipment available, as well as toy chests and game consoles for children and teens to enjoy. A babysitting service is also provided, giving you the opportunity to spend a much-needed evening together as a couple.

Lepic Villa Hotel
Rue Lepic
Cocody
Abidjan

+225 22 46 34 57

https://www.hotel-lepic.com/english.html

Rooms: from 141,000 XOF

content.title: Saakan, Abidjan's best restaurant

introduction.small: Emblematic address in town, Saakan will undoubtedly seduce you with its revisited typical recipes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Saakan, Abidjan's best restaurant

paragraphs.text:
After several trips around the world, chef Christelle Vougo has taken upon herself to experiment with a new pairing: revisiting her country's cooking while drawing inspiration from the culinary traditions of Japan or Thailand (countries that she often visited). Assisted by her husband Frank Anet, who took table service duties, she won on three counts at the very first Abidjan Restaurant Awards. The couple is now viewed as the local gastronomic figurehead.

Amid stripped-down and elegant decoration, the chef offers generous servings of flavourful dishes. For starters, you will find an Ivorian take on smoked salmon or an ostrich carpaccio that will prepare you for the wonders of the n'damla beef served with sweet potato mash, or the mushroom stew in spicy chocolate sauce. Unless you opt for the lobster and prawn choukouya, best paired with an alloco (plantain fried in oil) or an attiéké (cassava couscous). You need no excuse to dive into their delicious desserts: the baobab cream or the grotto yogurt (curds-based Ivorian iced speciality) hit their mark. Lovers of good food, you know what to do… and where to go!

Saakan
Plateau
Avenue Chardy (in front of AIP Abidjan)
Abidjan

+225 20 32 13 58

www.saakan.ci/

Menu: around 29,500 XOF

content.title: Quai 40, the spirit of recovery

introduction.small: At Quai 40, you can try the unusual and ecological experience of sleeping inside a container.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Quai 40, the spirit of recovery

paragraphs.text:
In Yasmine Hussein Farhat's garden in Abidjan, you will find five containers, sitting there as if the ocean (which is just 150 metres away as the crow flies) had left them there after an extraordinary tidal wave. Now transformed into guest rooms with all the modern comforts – including a luxurious bed, bathroom, and kitchenette – these seafaring giants, sumptuously painted in royal blue, each have their own history and bear the name of their final home port, such as Charleston (South Carolina, USA), Ningbo (China), and Nhava Sheva (India).

By giving them a second lease of life, the owner pays tribute to the region's port activity, while at the same time promoting an eco-friendly philosophy to make Quai 40's ecological impact as small as possible – by using very low energy consumption LED lighting, reusing rainwater for watering the garden, etc. In a soothing garden with paths created by pebbles and coconut shells, each room has its own terrace and looks like an island of tranquillity, all in the very heart of Abidjan's city centre!

Quai 40
Ruelle Asna
Boulevard de Marseille
Zone 3
Abidjan

+225 02 84 32 20

https://www.quai40.com/

Rooms: from 71,000 XOF

content.title: Man, the “City of 18 Mountains”

introduction.small: In the west of Ivory Coast, surrounded by majestic reliefs, Man promises you magical adventures in the heart of nature.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Man, the “City of 18 Mountains”

paragraphs.text:
For another change of scenery, simply travel to the western part of Ivory Coast, where the landscapes are radically different from those of the south. In particular, head for the city of Man, the capital of the Tonkpi region, which is entirely dominated by mountains and is a delight for outdoor activity enthusiasts. With this city of 150,000 inhabitants as a starting point, there are countless natural sites within reach of your walking poles.

In the heart of the forest, which is home to hundreds of rare species of butterflies and dragonflies, impressive liana bridges help you to cross awe-inspiring waterfalls. Meet the monkeys of the sacred forest of Gbêpleu, who will mind their own business, barely noticing your presence.

If you have a head for heights, you should take at least half a day to explore the Dent de Man. To reach the summit, you will need to climb a few small rocks, which will delight the younger members of your party. Once you've made it to the top, you will be rewarded with an incredible view of the city of Man nestled in the valley below, as well as the surrounding mountains, whose silhouettes gradually reveal themselves in the mist.

Man
Ivory Coast

https://www.cotedivoiretourisme.ci/index.php/actualites-tourisme/2387-a-la-decouverte-touristiques-de-la-ville-de-man

content.title: Manawa Café, the relaxing spot

introduction.small: Whether for a gourmet break or simply to please the eye, this coffee shop – also offering a boutique and gallery – is a looker.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Manawa Café, the relaxing spot

paragraphs.text:
In a fantastic mix of styles and periods, various objects take centre stage at Manawa Café, like genuine works of art. And there will assuredly be something for everyone. If you feel peckish, start off with some bissap juice – made of dried hibiscus flowers – that you could pair with a delicious waffle with honey for instance. In the meantime, and while comfortably settled in your bench seat, gaze at the retro-chic furniture, decorative trinkets, cushions printed with afro patterns and crockery made in Africa. Shopping addicts will be in wonderland as everything has a price tag here! Depending on your mood, you may leave with a painting, a beautiful wicker armchair or a statuette under your arm. You will even find an area devoted to local craft, created by artists from the continent. A perfect blend of cultural and culinary pleasures!

Manawa Café
Riviera 3 (in front of the International Community School)
Abidjan

+225 04 16 16 16

https://fr-fr.facebook.com/manawacafe/

Menu: around 5,250 XOF

content.title: Discovering Abidjan's concept stores

introduction.small: To unearth some truly unique local treasures, explore the city's trendiest boutiques.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discovering Abidjan's concept stores

paragraphs.text:
Perusing the concept stores of Abidjan will not only grant you the best souvenirs to take home, but will also be a truly fascinating experience. If you're on the lookout for local products, make sure to head to the Comptoir des Artisans. From fashion to home accessories and luxury chocolate, you'll find it all here, including a tea salon. If you're interested in sustainable development, a look at Nota Bene is a must, where you can find unique wax print items made locally in Ivory Coast, such as cushions, purses, children's clothing and even beach accessories. Chic and trendy style-lovers will adore Ettyka, which is spread over 200 sqm with 50 brands featuring ready-to-wear fashion, fine ornaments and household textiles, all exclusively made on the African continent. For a colourful fireworks display, ascend one floor and discover the “Espace des Créateurs” creators' space, where you can catch a glimpse of the impressive skill of local couturiers, from Ethnic Sikka to Nadia Druide and Naïma Dolls. Finally, if you're into travel and well-being, Dozo has an exciting shopping experience to offer you! There you'll find leather sandals, homemade handbags and even natural cosmetic products.

Comptoirs des Artisans
15, rue du Lycée Technique
Abidjan
+225 78 22 22 08
https://comptoirdesartisans.ci/

Nota Bene Créations
Rue Lumière
Abidjan
+225 08 08 06 79
https://fr-fr.facebook.com/benedicte.meurant/

Ettyka
Rue du Commerce
Abidjan

https://www.facebook.com/ettykalespacedescreateurs/

Dozo

content.title: Assinie and Assouindé: the art of doing nothing

introduction.small: The heavenly beaches of the Aby Lagoon spread about 100 km away from Abidjan, between traditional villages and seaside resorts.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Assinie and Assouindé: the art of doing nothing

paragraphs.text:
Ivory Coast has its very own Riviera! A 90-minute drive from Abidjan, the Assinie peninsula reveals spectacular scenery where the shoreline extends for about thirty kilometres. Assinie boasts a balance of authenticity and high-end tourism, and is both a fishing village and a seaside resort popular with Abidjan's elite. With jet skiing, pirogue boat trips, water tubing, cruises and much more on offer, there is no shortage of activities to try. However, there's absolutely nothing stopping you from simply laying out your towel or deckchair on the white sand of this idyllic beach to relax. Known as the “Saint Tropez of Africa”, the village of Assinie has been attracting an increasing number of visitors ever since the Ivorian reggae singer Alpha Blondy wrote a song about it in 1998. It is also well-known internationally thanks to the French cult comedy film, French Fried Vacation (1978).

Less than 20 kilometres away, you can also explore the charming little village of Assouindé, with its thatched houses, colourful shops and red laterite streets lined with coconut palms. In this resort – which is less frequented but just as enchanting as its neighbour – you can enjoy both a delightfully relaxing break and the unspoilt charm of the seaside scrubland.

Assinie beach
Assinie

Assouindé beach
Assouindé

content.title: Regional history uncovered at the Musée des Civilisations

introduction.small: The Musée des Civilisations (Museum of Civilisations) will help you to discover a great deal about the history of Ivory Coast.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Regional history uncovered at the Musée des Civilisations

paragraphs.text:
Once a craft centre opened on by the colonial administration, the Museum of Civilisations of Ivory Coast is now a living memory of regional heritage. With some 15,000 authentic objects, dating from 10,000 BC right up to the 21st century, the museum, which operates under the supervision of the Ivorian Ministry of Culture and Francophonie, is a veritable institution – former Senegalese President Léopold Sédar Senghor described it as “one of the richest museums of African art in the world”.

Although its collection suffered the loss of 120 valuable pieces during the 2010-2011 Ivorian political crisis, the museum reopened its doors to the public in 2017, more ambitious than ever. Now completely renovated, the Museum of Civilisations displays works from all regions of Ivory Coast, unique testimonies of the country's history: masks, ornaments, musical instruments, Palaeolithic tools and even a gilded bust of Félix Houphouët-Boigny, father of Ivorian independence. And the colossal elephant's skull in the entrance hall is sure to fascinate both young and old visitors alike.

Musée des Civilisations de Côte d'Ivoire
32, boulevard Carde
Abidjan

+225 20 22 20 56

https://www.facebook.com/museeciv.renaissance1942/

content.title: Abidjan's Hotel Particulier, a unique garden hotel

introduction.small: Secluded behind a bamboo wall, this family home in Cocody has been transformed into a boutique hotel surrounded by nature.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Abidjan's Hotel Particulier, a unique garden hotel

paragraphs.text:
An undisruptable calm reigns in the garden, only interrupted by the flight of a hummingbird. And yet, just a few metres before passing through the peristyle entrance, the buzz of the city was still ringing in your ears! But rest assured, you were not just transported to a parallel universe, you simply entered the Hotel Particulier. Far from the concrete of the Vieux-Cocody old town, this establishment was conceived as an urban getaway; a soothing sanctuary entirely dedicated to nature.

At the front desk, woody scents will delight the senses, complementing the green and brown hues that are to be found in the surrounding decor. When it comes to the rooms at the Hotel Particulier, some of which offering their own private garden, they evoke the colours of African diversity, from Marrakech to Zanzibar. Homemade herbal tea infusions, organic cosmetics and an open-air shower complete the enchanting atmosphere of this charming family home, which has now been transformed into a boutique hotel. Tucked up in your cosy nest here, there is no doubt that your nights will be filled with sweet dreams of travel and adventure.

Hotel Particulier Abidjan
Route du lycée Technique
Vieux-Cocody
Abidjan

+225 22 44 16 16

https://www.hotelparticulier-abj.com/

Rooms: from 108,000 XOF

content.title: Escape to nature from the frenzy of city life

introduction.small: Take a break in Banco National Park, in the heart of the city, or Bingerville Botanical Garden.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Escape to nature from the frenzy of city life

paragraphs.text:
With is bustling energy and status as the economic capital of the country – with the nation's political and administrative centres being established in Yamoussoukro – Abidjan truly lives up to its reputation as the “Manhattan of the Tropics”. But sometimes we all need to get away from the hustle and bustle around us and escape in search of tranquillity. In Abidjan, nature lovers can recharge their batteries in Banco National Park, an expansive green space and hydraulic reservoir in the city. Bordering the city's northern motorway, the park's 3,500 hectares of primary forest are home to a number of specimens of chimpanzees, dwarf antelopes, birds and butterflies. It might surprise you to know that, along with Rio de Janeiro, Abidjan is the only metropolis in the world where a true virgin forest flourishes.

Further east, less than 20 km from the city centre, you can relax in the centuries-old Bingerville Botanical Garden, which has been classified as a historical monument since 1991. Initially a scientific laboratory in its capacity as a test garden, when cultivating cocoa, coffee and palm plants was first introduced to Ivory Coast, it now showcases the thriving Ivorian ecosystem. With its pathways also accessible to cyclists, the Botanical Garden is the perfect place for families in search of calm and rejuvenation.

Banco National Park
Abidjan
+225 22 41 40 59

Bingerville Botanical Garden
Bingerville
+225 48 22 70 98

content.title: Galleries galore

introduction.small: Abidjan's cultural scene is bursting at the seams with art galleries, each more remarkable than the last. And these incredible spaces are just waiting for you to visit!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Galleries galore

paragraphs.text:
Abidjan is an art-lover's paradise. At Cécile Fakhoury's gallery, the emphasis is on works from the African continent, with numerous exhibitions where artists can let their strong identities and poetic universes shine. LouiSimone Guirandou Gallery promotes contemporary art by advocating an avant-garde style that has earned its founder, Simone Guirandou N'Diaye, a reputation that transcends borders. Houkami Guyzagn promotes young visual artists from Ivory Coast and organises regular openings, conferences and “art and drinks” sessions with the aim of making this place a unique space for meetings and exchanges. At the M'Pataô gallery, 1,200 sqm of space houses more than 1,600 exceptional pieces of traditional and ethnic art to help you discover the rich diversity of Africa's cultural heritage. Finally, Fondation Charles Donwahi advocates a love of the arts without borders: sculptures, paintings, graffiti, photographs, short and feature-length films; the artistic programming here boasts eclecticism and subjectivity. And you can even enjoy a drink and sample the culinary delights of young chef Julien Coulibaly here.

Galerie Cécile Fakhoury
Boulevard Latrille (between Sodemi and Immeuble Carbone)
Abidjan
+225 22 44 66 77
https://cecilefakhoury.com/en/

Galerie LouiSimone Guirandou
Rue C27 (behind Cité Universitaire Mermoz and adjoining the Goethe Institut Cocody)
Abidjan
+225 22 54 04 61
https://louisimoneguirandou.gallery/?lang=en

Galerie Houkami Guyzagn
Cocody Riviera Bonoumin
Abidjan
+225 22 43 55 12
https://houkamiguyzagn.com/accueil.php

Galerie M'Pataô
Rond-point de la Riviera Palmeraie
Résidence Plein Sud
Cocody

Fondation Charles Donwahi
Boulevard des Martyrs
Abidjan
+225 22 41 45 49
https://www.facebook.com/FondationDonwahi/

content.title: The artistic writing's on the wall in Abidjan

introduction.small: Driven by Ivorians' passion for art and creation, street art thrives beyond social and cultural borders in the streets of Abidjan.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The artistic writing's on the wall in Abidjan

paragraphs.text:
Although fairly unknown just a few years ago, street art is increasingly making its presence known on the city's walls. Go on a hunt for giant frescoes and try to spot the work of artist YZ among the many different pieces you'll see. With her Street Vendors project, the renowned Franco-British street artist combines art and politics by portraying street vendors in the city's different neighbourhoods. Far from the precariousness of their social condition – they are all street vendors, recyclers of consumer goods, windscreen washers – these women are represented in a sensitive and dignified way here.

Another impressive artistic achievement, the painted walls of the former Partners' Village from the Jeux de la Francophonie (Francophone Games) in Treichville, are also worth a visit. When the Games were held in Abidjan in 2017, young graffiti artists were invited to let their creativity flow out onto the village's huge facades. As a result, several dozen colourful works on the themes of commitment, solidarity and artistic expression have now completely reshaped the urban landscape, and the project was one of the first exploring alternative culture in Abidjan.

content.title: Shopping in Abidjan

introduction.small: Whether large or small, modern or traditional, specialising in crafts or food, Abidjan's markets are simply not to be missed if you want to really get to know the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Shopping in Abidjan

paragraphs.text:
What better way to get a real feel of Abidjan than by exploring its markets, which are as varied as its different neighbourhoods? The figurehead for local crafts – Abidjan's artisanal centre (known as the CAVA – Centre Artisanal de la Ville d'Abidjan) – is without question an absolute must-see in Ivory Coast's economic capital. The fifty or so market stalls, set up in red brick and earthenware huts, make up a sort of village where each craftsman sells their own specialised creations; from jewellery to sculpture, fashion to painting, and musical instruments to crystal work.

For a more traditional market, but one by no means less popular with locals, head towards the Treichville neighbourhood, known as the city of n'zassa (which means “mixture” in the Akan language). Here you will find a chaotic concentration of all the variety Abidjan has to offer, from second-hand clothing to high-tech gadgets and smoked fish stalls.

At the heart of the affluent Embassy District, halfway between the CAVA and the Treichville market, the Cocody Saint-Jean market also attracts a great many of Abidjan's residents. In this sprawling modern labyrinth with over 400 shops, you will be able to enjoy the very best in food, fashion, beauty and traditional restaurants.

CAVA (Centre Artisanal de la Ville d'Abidjan)
Boulevard du Canal (close to Abidjan Karting)
Abidjan
+225 07 21 95 76

Treichville market
Avenue Victor Biaka
Abidjan
+225 51 60 49 18

Cocody Saint-Jean market
Boulevard de France
Abidjan
+225 03 22 22 69

content.title: The Bushman Café Hotel: Abidjan's cultural meeting point

introduction.small: Much more than a café and hotel, this exceptional place is a real melting pot of African culture. Welcome to one of the city's trendiest places to be!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Bushman Café Hotel: Abidjan's cultural meeting point

paragraphs.text:
The Bushman Café Hotel, which has become an essential part of Abidjan's scenery since its opening in 2016, is an establishment like no other. This astonishing living space promotes art in all its diverse forms by mixing several styles from all eras in an uncomplicated way. If you're passionate about art, you've come to the right place, as the Bushman Café Hotel exhibits its artwork – paintings, sculptures, as well as handmade furniture – in direct contact with its guests, like a living museum.

Upstairs, eight bright and spacious rooms, with four-poster beds, murals and stone-tiled bathrooms, welcome all lovers of African culture. You can then head to the Wêlé restaurant to sample the chef's Afro-fusion cuisine and quench your thirst with an Ivorian coffee before continuing to the Shakara Lounge for an evening of Afro House. And if you're still looking for that little extra, the space also offers a natural swimming pool, a sauna and a gym where you can even take one-to-one yoga classes.

Bushman Café Hotel
Riviéra-M'Pouto
Cocody
Abidjan

+225 59 49 66 51

https://www.facebook.com/BushmanCafe/

Rooms: from 56,000 XOF

content.title: St. Paul's Cathedral in Abidjan: a modernist sanctuary

introduction.small: Overlooking the Ivorian lagoon coast with its 70-metre high bell tower, Abidjan's St. Paul's Cathedral stuns visitors with its grandeur and impressive architecture.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: St. Paul's Cathedral in Abidjan: a modernist sanctuary

paragraphs.text:
Its contemporary appearance is a radical departure from the traditional style of other Catholic places of worship. After five years of work, St. Paul's Cathedral in Abidjan was completed in 1985 and has since quickly become one of the emblems of the city, primarily due to its unusual structure. The avant-garde construction, dominated by triangular shapes, plays with symbols, such as that of the Holy Trinity or the tent – a metaphor for hospitality – through the immense concrete veil that covers the summit. On the façade, the walls plunge forwards and are reminiscent of an elephant's tusk pushing down into the ground. However, the most impressive part is the main bell tower, facing the coast. It has the silhouette of a 70-metre high giant who, like an allegory of the African man, seems capable of towing a mountain along. In just a short time, St. Paul's Cathedral, the biggest in the whole of Africa, has managed to well and truly capture the hearts of the people of Abidjan.

St. Paul's Cathedral in Abidjan
Abidjan

+225 20 21 20 26

content.title: Zen interlude at Kajazoma Concept

introduction.small: In this atypical and multifunctional space, expect a most original experience, night and day.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Zen interlude at Kajazoma Concept

paragraphs.text:
Away from the city's bustle, there is a haven of peace that only the most curious know about. Behind a big grey wall, a few banana trees and a small door, you will find one of Cocody's most unusual addresses. Just like a show house, it is arranged with several living areas, from the apatam (typical shed with a roof made of palm tree leaves) to the art gallery, the garden or the small salons scattered around the swimming pool. The decoration is eclectic, with contemporary paintings next to Ashanti stools and Malian masks scattered around waste material, renovated objects and old furniture.

As for the restaurant side, elegant and refined, it conveys a subtle mix of Ivorian, Cameroonian and European influences. Open for both lunch and dinner, it offers spicy sautéed shrimp or a lentil salad with raspberry vinegar for starters. Impossible to resist the fish skewers with pili-pili (red hot peppers) or the duck confit served with yam gratin and cassava sticks. The citrus fruit salad with cinnamon brings the meal to a perfect end.

Note that at Kajazoma Concept, decorative elements are all for sale. A blessing for all lovers of Ivorian culture!

Kajazoma Concept
2, plateaux Boulevard Latrille
Abidjan

+225 22 41 78 62

Menu: around 14,400 XOF

content.title: Sofitel Abidjan Hotel Ivoire: luxury reborn

introduction.small: Now completely renovated, the Sofitel Abidjan Hotel Ivoire has regained its former glory and is fast establishing itself as one of the country's must-visit establishments.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sofitel Abidjan Hotel Ivoire: luxury reborn

paragraphs.text:
As a symbol of the “Ivorian economic miracle” when it was opened in the affluent region of Abidjan in 1963, the Hotel Ivoire dances to the beat of national events. Long considered to be one of the most modern buildings on the entire African continent, a number of famous celebrities such as Michael Jackson, Barry White, Stevie Wonder and even Rihanna have graced its halls. Today, after a complete renovation, this 100-metre high skyscraper has regained its former star quality. Now managed by the Sofitel Group, the five-star hotel combines African culture, with many works by talented local artists, and French luxury, with its high-end spa. Its balcony rooms overlook the Plateau and the Ebrié Lagoon, but you can also enjoy an exceptional view of Cocody from the Toit d'Abidjan, one of the establishment's four restaurants. Chef Jérôme Cartailler puts his own spin on the authentic flavours of French gastronomy to provide you with a unique dining experience.

Sofitel Abidjan Hotel Ivoire
Boulevard Hassan II
Abidjan

+225 22 48 26 26

https://sofitel.accor.com/hotel/8844/index.en.shtml

Rooms: from 145,000 XOF

content.title: Welcome to Toa, the lounge that took Abidjan by storm

introduction.small: For drinks after work or a cocktail tasting with your loved one or some friends, look no further: Toa will be your favourite HQ.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Welcome to Toa, the lounge that took Abidjan by storm

paragraphs.text:
Known among all locals for its panoramic views, Toa and its elegant rooftop offer the perfect setting to gaze at “Babi” from a different angle. In this welcoming and sophisticated place, the soothing decoration – straight from Bali – consists of waterfalls, statues of Buddha, palm and bamboo trees, Indonesian parasols and white wicker chairs, providing a calm and peaceful atmosphere. Whether you choose to stay inside or escape to the rooftop, the eclectic music selection of jazz, Latin or electronic tunes (depending on the night) is enchanting.

The menu takes you around the world, with a skilful blend of cultures. Tapas to share, Thai shrimp, ribs and sweet potato fries or satay beef… so much to choose from! Your selection will be best paired with a glass of champagne or a signature cocktail – to be enjoyed in moderation, of course. It will then be time for you to join the dancefloor where light displays will make you king of queen of the night!

Le Toa
Le Massaï building
3rd floor
Boulevard Valéry Giscard d'Estaing
Abidjan

+225 07 44 44 52

https://fr-fr.facebook.com/espritloungebar/

Menu: around 15,000 XOF
